block.p: ATTRACTIONS
Museums and Sites

AMERICAN MUSEUM OF THE MOVING IMAGE, 34-12 36th Street, at 35th Avenue, Astoria, Queens. ''Behind the Mirror: American Film in the 1950's,'' through Sept. 3. Tomorrow at 2 p.m., John Sturges's ''Bad Day at Black Rock'' (1954); at 4:30 p.m., Emile De Antonio's ''Point of Order'' (1964). Sunday at 2 p.m., Richard Brooks's ''Blackboard Jungle'' (1955); at 4 p.m., Gene Fowler Jr.'s ''I Was a Teenage Werewolf'' (1957). Tomorrow and Sunday at 6:30 p.m., Claude Chabrol's ''Bonnes Femmes'' (1960). All activities are free with museum admission unless otherwise indicated. Admission: $8.50; the elderly and students, $5.50; ages 5 to 18, $4.50; 4 and under, free. Information: (718) 784-0077.
ATTRACTIONS
Museums and Sites

AMERICAN MUSEUM OF THE MOVING IMAGE, 34-12 36th Street, at 35th Avenue, Astoria, Queens. ''Behind the Mirror: American Film in the 1950's,'' through Sept. 3. Tomorrow at 2 p.m., John Sturges's ''Bad Day at Black Rock'' (1954); at 4:30 p.m., Emile De Antonio's ''Point of Order'' (1964). Sunday at 2 p.m., Richard Brooks's ''Blackboard Jungle'' (1955); at 4 p.m., Gene Fowler Jr.'s ''I Was a Teenage Werewolf'' (1957). Tomorrow and Sunday at 6:30 p.m., Claude Chabrol's ''Bonnes Femmes'' (1960). All activities are free with museum admission unless otherwise indicated. Admission: $8.50; the elderly and students, $5.50; ages 5 to 18, $4.50; 4 and under, free. Information: (718) 784-0077.

AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West and 79th Street. ''Fighting Dinosaurs: New Discoveries From Mongolia,'' featuring one of the most famous fossil finds in the world; through Oct. 29. ''Mongolia Observed: Photographs Present and Past,'' featuring 40 color images by Robert Peck and black-and-white photographs by the explorer Ray Chapman Andrews from the 1920's and 30's. Imax films are ''To Be an Astronaut'' and ''Dolphins.'' In the Imax Theater tonight and tomorrow night at 9, ''Laser Aerosmith in 3-D''; at 10, ''Laser Led Zeppelin.'' Laser show tickets: $12. Museum hours: Sundays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 8:45 p.m. Admission (suggested donation): $10 for adults; $7.50 for students and the elderly; $6 for children. Combination tickets are available. Information: (212) 769-5100; advance tickets: (212) 769-5200.

AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY'S ROSE CENTER FOR EARTH AND SPACE, Central Park West at 81st Street. This 333,500-square-foot, seven-floor, 120-foot-high exhibition and research center includes the new Hayden Planetarium, the Cullman Hall of the Universe and the Gottesman Hall of Planet Earth. The Hayden Planetarium contains the Space Theater, presenting ''Passport to the Universe,'' and the Big Bang Theater, featuring narrated visual and audio effects simulating the beginning of the universe. ''Starry Nights: Fridays Under the Sphere,'' music tonight from 5:45 to 8, with Bobby Sanabria y Quinteto Ache, through next Friday. Free with admission; food and cash bar. ''Full Moon: Apollo Mission Photographs of the Lunar Landscape,'' from NASA's Apollo missions to the moon; through Sept. 23. Hours: Sundays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays to 8:45 p.m. Space shows run throughout the day. Admission (suggested donation) to the American Museum of Natural History, which includes the Rose Center: $10; for students and the elderly, $7.50; children 12 and under, $6; under 2, free. Admission to the museum, the Rose Center and the Hayden Planetarium space show: $19; students and the elderly, $14; children 12 and under, $11.50; under 2, free. Information: (212) 769-5100. Reservations: (212) 769-5200.

HISTORIC RICHMONDTOWN, Staten Island Historical Society, 441 Clarke Avenue, Richmondtown. More than 25 buildings from the late 17th century to the 19th century, restored and furnished. This village and outdoor museum depict the history of Staten Island and the surrounding region. In ''Living History,'' during the summer season (through Sept. 1), costumed interpreters will demonstrate the skills and trades of their earlier counterparts, including the tinsmith, storekeeper and dollmaker. ''Civil War Encampment Weekend,'' tomorrow and Sunday from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m., recreates the camps, skirmishes and lifestyles of Union and Confederate armies, with cannon displays, soldiers, camp followers and a living history tour. Admission: $5; $2.50 for the elderly and children 6 to 16; under 6, free. Tomorrow night from 8 to 11, Regimental Ball, including torch lights, music, 19th-century dance; visitors may dress in style of the period. Free. The exhibition ''Toys!'' will run through December 2001. Guided tours are available. Hours through Sept. 1: Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 1 to 5 p.m. Admission: $4; the elderly and children 6 to 18, and students, $2.50; 5 and under, free. Information: (718) 351-1611.

MUSEUM OF CHINESE IN THE AMERICAS, 70 Mulberry Street, Chinatown. Silkscreened banners and other works by Brenda Joy Lem, through Aug. 26. On permanent display is ''Where Is Home? Chinese in the Americas,'' a collection of photographs and other artifacts, and ''Family Portraits,'' photographs of Chinatown residents. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, noon to 5 p.m.; closed holidays. Admission: $3; the elderly and students, $1; 12 and under and museum members, free. Information: (212) 619-4785.

MUSEUM OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK, Fifth Avenue at 103rd Street. The museum collects, preserves and presents material related to the city's history. Tomorrow at 1 p.m. ''African Rhythms, Latino Roots: The Music of New York's Barrios,'' by the filmmaker Tony DeNonno. Sunday at 1 p.m., ''Growing Old in Spanish Harlem,'' a videotaped tour of the 1992 exhibition based on the work of Judith Freidenberg, who will be present. ''New York Now 2000: Contemporary Work in Photography,'' through Oct. 15. Hours: Tuesdays, 10 a.m. to 2 p.m., for registered groups only; Wednesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Suggested admission: $7; the elderly, students and children, $4; families, $12. Information: (212) 534-1672.

MUSEUM OF JEWISH HERITAGE: A LIVING MEMORIAL TO THE HOLOCAUST, 18 First Place, at West Street and Battery Place, Battery Park City, Lower Manhattan. Artifacts, documents, photographs, videos and film clips are included in exhibitions on the Holocaust and on Jewish life before and after World War II. ''Children of a Vanished World: Photographs by Roman Vishniac,'' through Oct. 20. Hours: Sundays through Wednesdays, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Thursdays until 8 p.m.; Fridays and the eves of Jewish holidays, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.; closed Saturdays. Admission: $7; students and the elderly, $5; children 5 and under, free. Tickets can be bought in advance through Ticketmaster, (212) 307-4007, or by calling the museum on the day of the visit, (212) 945-0039. Information: (212) 509-6130.

NEW-YORK HISTORICAL SOCIETY, 170 Central Park West, near 77th Street. ''Stork Club,'' including an environmental installation that mimics the floor plan of the club, and photographs and memorabilia belonging to the family of Sherman Billingsley, the owner of the club; on view through Oct. 1. ''Fit for a King,'' in celebration of Bastille Day, an 18th-century French chair owned by Marie Antoinette and Louis XIV at Versailles; through Sept. 3. ''Manhattan Contrasts,'' 20th-century paintings of New York; through Aug. 27. ''New York Inside Out,'' an exhibition portraying New Yorkers at home; through Sunday. ''The Changing Face of Liberty: Female Allegories of America,'' through Sept. 3. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $5; students and the elderly, $3; 12 and under, free. Information: (212) 873-3400.
Gardens

BROOKLYN BOTANIC GARDEN, 900 Washington Avenue, Prospect Heights. Through Sept. 16, butterfly and hummingbird trails open for tours, with related crafts and other activities on weekends. The Japanese Hill and Pond Garden is open. ''Photographs of Winners 1995-2000, Greenest Block in Brooklyn,'' through Aug. 26. Gallery hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. Admission: $3; $1.50 for students and the elderly; free for children 15 and under; free on Tuesdays, except holidays; free from 10 a.m. to noon on Saturdays. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 8 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Saturdays, Sundays and holidays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. The conservatory closes 30 minutes before the grounds. Information: (718) 623-7200.

NEW YORK BOTANICAL GARDEN, 200th Street and Kazimiroff Boulevard, Fordham, the Bronx. The grounds include more than 47 specialty gardens and plant collections. ''Swing,'' a seven-day festival beginning tomorrow, presented by the producers of the Broadway show, including related activities and a performance at 2 p.m., with free swing lessons. 24. The Exotic Courtyard Garden, with exotic tropical plants in 100 containers, is on display through Sept. 24. Through mid-September, the summer gardens are in bloom. Saturdays and Sundays at 12:30 p.m., 90-minute bird and butterfly walks. Through Aug. 31, ''Cool Off,'' Tuesdays through Sundays from 1 to 6 p.m., visitors can explore the green and shady getaways of the park and explore plants from around the world. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays and Monday holidays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Botanical garden admission: $3; students and the elderly, $2; children 2 to 12, $1; under 2, free. Conservatory admission: $3.50; students and the elderly, $2.50; children 2 to 12, $2; under 2, free. Grounds admission free for all on Wednesdays and from 10 a.m. to noon on Saturdays. There are combination packages. Parking: $5. Information: (718) 817-8700.

STATEN ISLAND BOTANICAL GARDEN, 1000 Richmond Terrace, Livingston. The garden covers 83 acres, with neo-Classical buildings that once housed retired seamen. Hours: daily, dawn to dusk. Free admission to the grounds. The one-acre New York Chinese Scholars' Garden is open. ''China: Ancient Art and Sciences,'' featuring 13 artisans from China demonstrating their craft and 300 works of art; through Oct. 1. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission to the Chinese Scholars' Garden: $7.50; $5 for the elderly and students and children under 12; under 1, free. Information: (718) 273-8200.

WAVE HILL, West 249th Street and Independence Avenue, Riverdale, the Bronx. Gardens, greenhouses and woodlands are part of the 28-acre garden and cultural institution. ''Welcome,'' works by 11 artists exploring ideas of home and the relationship between people and nature; through Sunday. Tuesdays through Sundays, 9 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. Admission: $4; students and the elderly, $2; Saturdays, free until noon. Information: (718) 549-3200; reservations: extension 213.
Cruises

ADIRONDACK, leaving from Chelsea Piers Sports and Entertainment Complex, 23rd Street on the Hudson River. An 80-foot schooner that goes on two-hour sails daily around New York Harbor at 10:30 a.m., 1, 3:30, 6 and 9 p.m. Tickets: weekdays, $30 for all sails except the 6 and 9 p.m. sail, which is $40, and includes drinks; weekends, $35 for all sails except the 6 and 9 p.m. sail, which is $45, including drinks. Information: (800) 701-7245.

CIRCLE LINE CRUISES, leaving from Pier 83, 42nd Street at the Hudson River, Clinton. A two-hour, 24-mile cruise around southern Manhattan passing landmarks like Ellis Island and the United Nations, daily at 11 a.m., 2 p.m. and 4:30 p.m. Tickets: $20; children 12 and under, $10; the elderly, $16. A three-hour 35-mile cruise around all of Manhattan, daily at 9:30, 10:15 and 11:45 a.m., 12:30, 1:15, 2:45 and 3:30 p.m. Tickets: $24; children 12 and under, $12; the elderly, $19. ''Harbor Lights,'' daily at 7 p.m. Tickets: $20; children 12 and under, $10; the elderly, $16. ''The Beast,'' 30-minute speedboat ride in the harbor, daily, every hour on the hour, 11 a.m. to dusk, except Wednesdays, when it is 2 p.m. to dusk. Tickets: $15; children 5 to 12, $10. Information: (212) 563-3200.

WORLD YACHT, leaving from Pier 81, 41st Street at the Hudson River, Clinton. Daily dinner cruises along the West Side of Manhattan and around New York Harbor, from 7 to 10 p.m., boarding at 6 p.m. Prices: Fridays, $75; Saturdays, $79; Sundays, $67 (does not include beverages, taxes or gratuities). Brunch cruises sail on Sundays from 12:30 to 2:30 p.m., with boarding at 11:30 a.m. Price: $39.95. Information: (212) 630-8100.

N.Y. WATERWAY, leaving from Pier 78, West 38th Street and 12th Avenue, Clinton. Daily two-hour full Manhattan cruise, at 10:30 a.m. and 1:30 p.m., through Nov. 12. Tickets: $24; $19 for the elderly; $12 for children ages 3 to 12; 2 and younger, free. Daily, a 90-minute cruise of New York Harbor; at 10 a.m., 11 a.m., noon, 1 p.m., 2, 3 and 4 p.m. Tickets: $19; the elderly, $16; ages 3 to 12, $9; 2 and younger, free. Fridays at 10:15 p.m., disco cruise. Price: $19; $9 for children. A 70-minute twilight tour leaves daily, except Tuesday, at 8:45 p.m.; additional tours on Saturdays at 7:15 and 10:15 p.m. and on Sundays at 7:15. Tickets: $19; the elderly, $16; children, $9. Information: (800) 533-3779.

PIONEER, the historic schooner, sails from the South Street Seaport Museum's Pier 16, South and Fulton Streets, Lower Manhattan, for a two-hour cruise. Sunset cruises Tuesdays through Sundays at 7 p.m.; 9:30 p.m. sails Tuesdays through Saturdays; additional sails Saturdays and Sundays at 1 and 4 p.m. Tickets: sunset cruises $25; other sails $20, $15 for students and the elderly and $12 for children 12 and under.
EVENTS

''MACY'S TAP-O-MANIA,'' Herald Square. The annual event is expected to draw thousands of amateur and professional tap dancers. To break the current record, at least 6,777 dancers are needed. Sunday at noon; registration is from 8 to 10:30 a.m. at Seventh Avenue and 35th Street. Information: (212) 494-1917.

''SUNSET JAM ON THE HUDSON,'' Wagner Park, Battery Park City, Lower Manhattan. Featuring a rotating trio of percussionists: Mary Knyshok, Peter Hawes and Pamela Patrick. Tonight at 6:30. Free. Sponsored by Battery Park City Parks Conservancy. Information: (212) 267-9700.

''A FOOD ADVENTURE OF GREENWICH VILLAGE.'' Combines tastings at local restaurants and specialty food stores with a stroll. Meets Tuesdays through Sundays at 11:30 a.m. Sponsored by Foods of New York. Fee: $25 (includes food). Information and meeting place: (732) 636-4650.
RECREATION

''CLUB TEAM CHAMPIONSHIP'' AND ''CHALLENGE OF THE UNATTACHED,'' Central Park. Two five-mile races tomorrow; the first begins at 8:30 a.m., the second at 9:30 a.m. Both races begin and end at the East Drive north of 99th Street. Sponsored by the New York Road Runners Club. Advance registration fee for the championship race, $7; for the challenge race, $17; $12 for club members; $10 for junior and senior club members. Race-day registration for challenge race, $22, $15 for club members; $12 for junior and senior club members. Information: (212) 860-4455.
ON THE STREET
WALL STREET COMMUNITY DAY FESTIVAL, Wall Street, from South to Water Street. Today, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.
LOWER EAST SIDE FESTIVAL, East Sixth Street between Avenue D and the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive. Tomorrow, 11 a.m. to 8 p.m.
14TH STREET SUMMERFEST, from Seventh to Eighth Avenue. Tomorrow, 11 a.m. to 7 p.m. Sponsored by St. Bernard's Church.
SEVENTH AVENUE TOURIST EXPO, from 47th to 57th Street, Manhattan. Tomorrow, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Sponsored by the New York Young Republicans.
UNIVERSITY PLACE FESTIVAL, from Eighth to 13th Street, West Village. Tomorrow, 11 a.m. to 7 p.m. Sponsored by Village Visiting Neighbors.
HARLEM WEEK FESTIVAL, 135th Street, from Fifth to St. Nicholas Avenue. Tomorrow and Sunday, 8 a.m. to 9 p.m.
MADISON AVENUE SUMMERFEST, from 42nd to 57th Street. Sunday, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Sponsored by Workmen's Circle.
INDIA DAY PARADE, Madison Avenue from 40th to 27th Street. Sunday at 1 p.m. Sponsored by the Federation of Indians Association.
FOREST HILLS/REGO PARK FESTIVAL, 63rd Drive from Queens Boulevard to Alderton Street and on the Queens Boulevard Service Road, Queens. Sunday, 11 a.m. to 7 p.m.
WALKING TOURS

YANKEE STADIUM, the Bronx. An insider's tour, including Monument Park and the dugout. Meets many Fridays and Saturdays at noon at the press gate when the team is away. Fee, $8; $4 for children 14 and younger and the elderly. Information: (718) 579-4531.

''MONEY MATTERS: THE INTERIORS OF WALL STREET.'' A tour of noted lobbies in Lower Manhattan, including those at the Custom House, the Cunard Building and 1 Wall Street. Meets today at 1 p.m. on the steps of the Alexander Hamilton United States Custom House, 1 Bowling Green. Sponsored by the Municipal Art Society. Fee, $10, $8 for students, the elderly and members of the Municipal Art Society. Information: (212) 935-3960.

''BIZARRE AND ECCENTRIC EAST VILLAGE TOUR.'' visits tattoo and body piercing shops, emporiums for magic potions, leather collars and whips and an estimable French fries place. Meets tonight at 7 at the cube at Astor Place, St. Marks Place and Lafayette Street. Led by Michael Kaback. Fee: $15, plus cost of snacks. Information: (212) 370-4214.

''BEHIND THE FENCES WALKING TOURS,'' Prospect Park, Brooklyn. A free tour of the park's newly restored ravine. Saturdays at 3 p.m. and Sundays at 1 and 3 p.m through November. Sponsored by the Prospect Park Alliance and the Urban Park Rangers. Information: (718) 965-6988.

''STANFORD WHITE: SPLENDOR AND SCANDAL,'' Lower Manhattan. Looks at the life of the architect and the buildings he designed. Meets tomorrow at 6 p.m. at the Washington Arch. Fee, $15. Sponsored by Street Smarts N.Y. Information: (212) 969-8262.

''HIGHLIGHTS OF THE EAST VILLAGE: AN OVERVIEW TOUR IN TWO PARTS.'' Stops at landmarks, cemeteries, rock 'n' roll shrines and exterior locations used for films and television series from Astor Place to East 10th Street. Part I, tomorrow and Sunday at 11:45 a.m.; Part II, tomorrow and Sunday at 2:15 p.m. Fee, $11 for first part, $5 for the second walk. Sponsored by Gotham Walk. Information and meeting place: (212) 629-1886.

''HISTORIC LOWER MANHATTAN.'' This walking tour explores landmarks and historic sites of Colonial New York, with stops at the first Capitol and a building where George Washington slept. Meets tomorrow at 1 p.m. on the front steps of the Alexander Hamilton United States Customs House, 1 Bowling Green. Fee: $10. Sponsored by I'll Take Manhattan Tours. Information: (732) 270-5277.

''HELL'S KITCHEN HIKE'' tours the Midtown Manhattan area now known as Clinton. Meets tomorrow at 12:15 p.m. on the northeast corner of Eighth Avenue and 48th Street. Fee: $5. Sponsored by Adventure on a Shoestring. Information: (212) 265-2663.

''GHOSTS ON BROADWAY.'' Visits haunted theaters and a hotel. Meets tomorrow at 2 p.m. in front of the Belasco Theater, 44th Street near Avenue of the Americas. Fee: $10. Sponsored by Street Smarts N.Y. Information: (212) 969-8262.

''PUBS AND POLTERGEISTS.'' Tours the West Village, with stops at two of its oldest taverns. Meets tomorrow night at 6 in front of St. Luke's-in-the-Field Church at Hudson and Grove Streets. Fee: $10, not including drinks and tips. Sponsored by Street Smarts New York. Information: (212) 969-8262.

''IMMIGRANT NEW YORK.'' A multiethnic walking tour of the Lower East Side, Chinatown, Little Italy and other ethnic neighborhoods. Stops include the African Burial Ground, Mulberry Bend and sites associated with Sun Yat-sen, Mother Cabrini and Abraham Cahan. Meets today at 1 p.m. at the southeast corner of Broadway and Chambers Street. Fee: $12; students and the elderly, $10. Sponsored by Big Onion Walking Tours. Information: (212) 439-1090.

''AFFLUENT ENCLAVE,'' Manhattan, covers the Beekman Place-Sutton Place area with stops at the former residences of Irving Berlin, Greta Garbo and Rex Harrison. Meets Sunday at 2 p.m. at the northwest corner of 52nd Street and First Avenue. Fee: $5. Sponsored by Adventure on a Shoestring. Information: (212) 265-2663.

''VIEWS FROM THE PAST'' explores the history of the Sheep Meadow, Central Park. Meets Saturdays at 1 p.m. at the Dairy, midpark at 65th Street. Free. Sponsored by the Central Park Conservancy. Information: (212) 360-2726.

''THE JACK FINNEY 'TIME AND AGAIN' TOUR,'' Lower Manhattan, retraces the steps of the time traveler Simon Morley near the Tweed Courthouse. Meets tomorrow at 2 p.m. inside Blimpie's Restaurant, 38 Park Row, between Spruce and Beekman Streets. Fee, $12. Sponsored by Dr. Phil: New York Talks and Walks. Information: (888) 377-4455.

''JAZZ NIGHTS IN HARLEM.'' A tour of the area, followed by dinner and a stop at a jazz club. Meets tonight and tomorrow night at 7:30 at the northeast corner of Lenox Avenue and 125th Street. Fee: $45. Sponsored by Harlem Heritage Tours. Reservations: (212) 280-888.

TWILIGHT BROOKLYN BRIDGE TALK AND WALK. Discusses the Roebling family, instrumental in the building of the bridge, and the importance of the structure itself. Meets tomorrow at 6 p.m. in Blimpie's Restaurant, 38 Park Row, Lower Manhattan. Fee: $12. Sponsored by Dr. Phil: New York Talks and Walks. Information: (888) 377-4455.

''HISTORIC LOWER MANHATTAN AT TWILIGHT.'' Tours New York's first point of settlement, which is now a thriving financial center. Meets tomorrow at 5 p.m. on the steps of the Alexander Hamilton United States Customs House, 1 Bowling Green. Fee: $12, $10 for students and the elderly. Sponsored by Big Onion Walking Tours. Fee: $10; $8 students and the elderly. Information: (212) 439-1090.

''I'LL NEVER GO THERE ANYMORE: THE BOWERY,'' includes the area's notorious saloons, dance halls and flophouses. Meets tomorrow at 1 p.m. at the cube sculpture at Astor Place, at Eighth Street in the East Village. Sponsored by Big Onion Walking Tours. Fee: $12; $10 for students and the elderly. Information: (212) 439-1090.

''HAUNTED GREENWICH VILLAGE.'' The tour includes stops at the Hanging Elm and a haunted firehouse, town house and restaurant. Meets tomorrow at 2:30 p.m. on the southwest corner of Eighth Street and Fifth Avenue. Fee: $5. Sponsored by Adventure on a Shoestring. Information: (212) 265-2663.

''CHILD-FRIENDLY RAMBLE: BROOKLYN BRIDGE FOR YOUNG DREAMERS.'' explores the Brooklyn Bridge from a child's perspective. Meets tomorrow at noon inside Blimpie's restaurant, 38 Park Row, between Spruce and Beekman Streets, Lower Manhattan. Fee: $6. Sponsored by Dr. Phil's New York Talks and Walks. Information: (888) 377-4455.

''AN INSIDER'S VISIT TO THE EMPIRE STATE BUILDING.'' Led by John Tauranac, author of ''The Empire State Building: The Making of a Landmark,'' the tour focuses on the history and architecture of the building, including a visit to the dirigible mooring mast. Sunday at 1 p.m. Fee, $20. Sponsored by the 92nd Street Y. Information: (212) 996-1100.

''THE BATTLE OF BROOKLYN: THE REAL THING'' tours the site of the famous battle with John Gallagher, author of ''The Battle of Brooklyn 1776.'' Meets Sunday at 1 p.m. at the Lefferts Homestead, inside Prospect Park, near the Empire Boulevard entrance. Sponsored by the Brooklyn Center for the Urban Environment. Fee, $8; $6 for members; $5 for students and the elderly. Information: (718) 788-8500, extension 401.

''WALL STREET AREA TOUR: MONEY AND OTHER EVILS.'' Covers the titans of the financial world as well as those who challenged them. Meets Sunday at 1 p.m. on the steps of the National Museum of the American Indian, 1 Bowling Green. Fee, $10. Sponsored by Radical Walking Tours. Information: (718) 492-0069.

''ROCKEFELLER CENTER: ART AND ARCHITECTURE BETWEEN THE WARS.'' The history of this Art Deco monument, from the 1930's to the present. Led by Francis Morrone, an architectural historian. Meets Sunday at 1 p.m. in the courtyard of the Urban Center, 457 Madison Avenue, at 51st Street. Fee: $15; $12 for members. Sponsored by the Municipal Art Society. Information: (212) 935-3960.

''IDYLLIC ISLAND,'' Roosevelt Island. The tour includes the Blackwell House, the Octagon Tower and a mysterious lighthouse. Meets Sunday at 3:30 p.m. on the northwest corner of Second Avenue and 59th Street. Fee: $5 and $3 round-trip tramway fare. Sponsored by Adventure on a Shoestring. Information: (212) 265-2663.

''THE NOOKS AND CRANNIES OF GREENWICH VILLAGE.'' Covers the former residences of noted writers as well as cultural and social landmarks. Meets Sunday at 1 p.m. at the southeast corner of Fifth Avenue and 12th Street. Fee: $10. Sponsored by I'll Take Manhattan Tours. Information: (732) 270-5277.

''THE JEWISH LOWER EAST SIDE.'' Explores the historic settlements, once home to one of the largest Jewish communities in the world. Meets Sunday at 1 p.m. at the southeast corner of Essex and Delancey Streets. Fee: $12; $10 for students and the elderly. Sponsored by Big Onion Walking Tours. Information: (212) 439-1090.

''CROSS PARK PROMENADE.'' A free east-to-west tour of the Park, sponsored by the Central Park Conservancy. Meets Sunday at noon at the kiosk inside the 72nd Street and Fifth Avenue entrance. Information: (212) 360-2726.

UPPER EAST SIDE WALKING TOUR I, a tour that combines the history and architecture of the area and includes sights like the Sara D. Roosevelt Memorial House, the Colony Club, the Elizabeth Street Gardens and the Thomas R. Howell Mansion. Meets on Sunday at 2 P.M. at the southwest corner of East 58th Street and Park Avenue. Sponsored by New York City Cultural Walking Tours. Fee, $10. Information: (212) 979-2388.

ASTOR PLACE/EAST VILLAGE: ''THE OLD AND THE NEW,'' focuses on the history of the area. Meets Sunday at 2 p.m. at the southeast corner of East 11th Street and Second Avenue. Fee, $10. Sponsored by Bernie's New York. Information: (718) 655-1883.

HARLEM GOSPEL TOUR. This weekend, the site of an outdoor baptism. Meets on Sundays at 10 a.m. on the southwest corner of Lenox Avenue and 116th Street. Fee: $20. Sponsored by Harlem Heritage Tours. Information: (212) 280-7888.
